Another opinion

Though I was raised with a moderate Roman Catholic faith and have since largely shifted away from such rigid belief, there were always aspects of the Christian faith which puzzled me and which I never "got". They were repeated often enough in mass, but never fully explained. So, I wonder if those of you who think you understand these points could fill me in on their full meaning.
 
 1) Jesus sacrificed his life for the sins of humanity:
 The things I never understood about this include:
 
 - Why was a sacrifice necessary? Was this to appease the anger of God because so many humans were misbehaving (i.e. sinning)? What would God have done to humanity if a sacrifice / appeasement were never made? How does that potential action on God's part reflect on His image of being a benevolent and loving God?
 
 - I would think that, if humanity were sinning and wanted to appease God's anger or disappointment, then it should have been humans who should have made the sacrifice for their wrongful actions through atonement or punishment. In what way would the sacrifice of Jesus lift off the burden of sin from humanity? For example, if you have a large family and a few of the younger children misbehave, how would it resolve things to have the oldest responsible and good sibling be punished?
 
 2) Christianity is Monotheistic:
 
 - How exactly are Jesus and the Father one entity - i.e. two parts of the trinity? It seems like they are two. The holy spirit is also confusing - is it a being or a force?
 
 - What about all the angels and saints - they have spiritual powers that are similar to those of the minor gods and spirits of other religions. I have heard that their power is derived / given from God, which I might accept as being an explanation for how they themselves are not gods.
 
 - What about Satan? If his power is independent of God, then that would make him another god - meaning Christianity is not monotheistic. If his power is derived from God, then God can be blamed for the actions of Satan since He gives Satan the power to perform such actions.
 
 Those are the main questions I was puzzled by and they should suffice for the start of this potential discussion. I would be quite interested in any feedback you could give.

 - How exactly are Jesus and the Father one entity - i.e. two parts of the trinity? It seems like they are two. The holy spirit is also confusing - is it a being or a force?
